response.answer_text: Overall Hawaii people are very accepting. With almost 10 million new faces visiting the islands every year, it’s hard to worry about such things as gay relationships. Also, in the local culture, there has been a long history of fluid sexual identification as per the term Mahu. As a LGBTQ visitor, if you come to Honolulu and Waikiki you can expect to be quite welcome everywhere. Waikiki in particular would be a very comfortable place, although local families may be joining you on a crowded beach and with a predominately Asian culture, I would advise against overt expression of sexuality. There was some push-back many years ago when the same-sex marriage debate raged on, and perhaps parents did not want to have to explain to a six year old why those boys are kissing. Neighbor islands may be a little tougher but I really don’t know enough to say. So if you lay low, enjoy all the sights and sounds, and be civil in public, I can assure you will be treated well and respected. You may want to join the legions who marry here too. The scenery is gorgeous regardless of which side of the plate you swing from. I’ve had a few gay real estate clients over the years and they have been among the nicest people I’ve worked with.  Plus there is a great gay bar in Waikiki. See pic. My photo.

Yes, particularly the area around Kapahulu and Kalākaua. Across the street from Kapi’olani Park, the beach across the street is considered the gay beach. It’s where the annual gay picnic is held. is located. Hula’s is around the corner and across the street from the Honolulu Zoo, next to the Queen Kapiolani Hotel, on Kapahulu. Hula’s is probably the oldest gay bar in Honolulu. Check out its website Hula's Bar & Lei Stand | Gay Bar, Beach View Dining, Dance Party.. I love this bar and go whenever possible. They’ve got great drinks, good food, and a separate room for dancing. Hula’s is the bar in the photo someone else posted. They also have catamaran cruises, FYI. Hawai’i is gay-friendly, particularly on Oahu. Never had any problems with being openly lesbian in Hawai’i even when my partner and I went there in the early 90s. I’ve lived on Maui, in Hilo, on Kauai, and Oahu openly, with no problems.
